Harvard University is doing away with its early admissions program.
School officials say the program was unfair to minority and low income applicants.
Harvard's move follows a similar one made by the University of Delaware four months ago.
And we're joined now by Louis Hirsh.
He's the director of admissions at the University of Delaware.
And tell us, Mr. Hirsh, why did your university decide to do away with early admissions?
For exactly the reasons that Harvard cited this morning - a real concern that early decision programs were discriminating.
It really gets any student for whom money for college is an issue, whether there's significant financial need or possibility of merit based scholarships for a student.
These are people who really need to look at a range of different college choices and make what is the best decision financially as well as educationally for their students.
Well, explain that, if you will, for people who are unfamiliar with the admissions process.
Sure.
First of all, some of the programs are binding.
You commit yourself to - if you're admitted - to accepting the offer of admission as early as January and withdrawing all your college applications.
So you rally are making a commitment that you're bound to and can't change.
There are other programs that still allow you to deposit some of the admissions deposit by May 1.

The problem is there is such a welter of different plans that most families become very confused by them, and if your student is coming out of a high school that isn't terribly sophisticated about college guidance, you're likely to find this very confusing and very dispiriting, and I think that is also an important consideration.
It certainly was for us in, you know, eliminating early decision.
Now, the attraction of early admissions - as I understand it with universities - is that they get to lock in the best students.
That's right.

Now, it would seem that Harvard getting rid of early admissions wouldn't be that risky for them as they're usually attracting the top seniors in any high school class, but what about for state schools like yours?
Is it risky to get rid of?
Well, you know, it's a risk worth taking if it is.
We get 22,000 applications for freshmen admission.
We're by no means one of the largest schools in the country.
We're more of a medium-sized school.
But we do get one of the largest applicant pools.

I'm confident that the pluses for the University of Delaware are so evident to so many of our applicants that we will still enroll a terrific class without, frankly, the arm twisting that early decision programs impose on students.
So we'll see a year from now where we stand, but I'm frankly quite confident we made absolutely the right decision.
And I certainly have been hearing from a flood of guidance counselors and even some parents who have been thanking us for it.

I'm sure that Harvard's email is probably very active today as well with people who are simply appreciative of the fact that we're dropping a program that has come to cause more anxiety than anything else.
And do you think more schools will follow your lead and Harvard's lead?
I hope so.
I think we've made a decision that is in the best interest of students and I hope there will be more who will follow it.
But we'll see.
Louis Hirsh is the director of admissions at the University of Delaware.
Thank you for joining us.
Well, thank you for having me.
